A visual data mining methodology to conduct seismic facies analysis: Part 2 ---
Testing and comparison with other unsupervised clustering methods
Article  in  Geophysics · January 2009

CITATIONS
24

READS
106
3 authors, including:
Brault Jean-Jules
Polytechnique Montréal
14 PUBLICATIONS   247 CITATIONS
SEE PROFILE
Bruce Hart

118 PUBLICATIONS   2,513 CITATIONS
SEE PROFILE

A visual data mining methodology to conduct seismic facies analysis:
Part 2 — Testing and comparison with other unsupervised
clustering methods
Iván Dimitri Marroquín1, Jean-Jules Brault2, and Bruce S. Hart3
ABSTRACT

A visual data-mining approach to unsupervised clustering
analysis can be an effective tool for visualizing and under-
standing patterns inherent in seismic data i.e., seismic fa-
cies. The unsupervised clustering analysis is completely da-
ta-driven, requiring no external information e.g., well logs
to guide the seismic-trace classiﬁcation. We demonstrate the
application of the visual data-mining approach to seismic fa-
cies analysis on a real 3D seismic data volume. We select two
stratigraphic intervals, the ﬁrst including a Devonian pinna-
cle reef system and the second containing a Jurassic silici-
clastic channel system. Both analyses show major strati-
graphic features that can be deﬁned in horizon slices or other
types of visualization. However, the visual data-mining ap-
proach creates seismic facies maps with improved visual de-
tail, distinguishing seismic trace-shape variability in the data.
We also compare the facies maps with those obtained from a
commercial package for seismic facies classiﬁcation. Both
approaches created similar facies maps, but the visual strate-
gy better depicts subtle stratigraphic changes in the bodies
being imaged, offering insight into the nature of these
features.
INTRODUCTION

The objective of automatic seismic facies analysis is to bring out a
natural clustering structure in a data set based on the character of the
seismic response.Then, it is hoped that each cluster of seismic traces
can be related to a particular depositional environment and/or suite
of rock properties including, perhaps, ﬂuid content of the strati-
graphic bodies being imaged. In the unsupervised clustering analy-
sis discussed in part 1 Marroquín et al., 2009, we compare and

Manuscript received by the Editor 23 October 2007; revised manuscript received 11 June 2008; published online 31 December 2008.

.marroquin@pdgm.com.
2École Polytechnique Montréal, Département de Génie électrique, Campus de 1’Université de Montréal, Montréal, Canada. E-mail: jean-jules.brault@
polymtl.qc.ca.
3Formerly McGill University, Earth & Planetary Sciences Department, Montréal; Canada; presently ConocoPhillips, Houston, Texas, U.S.A. E-mail: bruce
.hart@conocophillips.com.
© 2009 Society of Exploration Geophysicists.All rights reserved.

evaluate various clustering algorithms. Tests conducted on simple
2D data sets showed that a visual data-mining approach, developed
by Guo et al. 2005 to analyze spatial data, provides an environment
that facilitates the recognition of the inherent cluster structure in the
data sets. This visual strategy was applied to 2D seismic models. In
spite of the simple nature of the synthetic traces, the 2D seismic
models have characteristics similar to those of real seismic data
e.g., highly correlated and continuous data. The visual strategy
successfully identiﬁed the correct number of end-member seismic
facies.
The current paper demonstrates how the visual strategy identiﬁed
in Marroquín et al. 2009 is useful for seismic facies analysis of 3D
seismic data. We test the method on carbonate and clastic deposits
from the Williston Basin. We compare the facies maps with horizon-
slice displays to show how lateral changes in seismic facies can bet-
ter deﬁne major stratigraphic features. We then compare our results
to facies maps obtained using a commercial package. We conclude
that the visual strategy we tested is useful for seismic facies analysis
and provides several advantages over existing methods.
GENERAL GEOLOGIC SETTING

The Williston Basin forms the southeastern margin of the Western
Canada Sedimentary Basin. Signiﬁcant hydrocarbon reserves have
made this a major exploration region Kent and Christopher, 1994.
The Williston Basin extends from the southern part of Manitoba and
Saskatchewan to the northern part of North Dakota and Montana
Figure 1 and is a roughly circular depression that covers about
250,000 km2 96,525 mi2; Christopher et al., 1973. Aitken 1993a,
1993b and Kent and Christopher 1994 provide details of its evolu-
tion. Subsidence of the basin began during the Ordovician Period,
and it has undergone episodic subsidence through the rest of the
Phanerozoic eon. In this paper, we focus on Devonian and Jurassic
strata.

PROCEDURE FOR UNSUPERVISED
CLUSTERING ANALYSIS

To conduct the unsupervised clustering analysis, we followed the
framework proposed in Marroquín et al. 2009. The ﬁrst step is to
deﬁne the size of the analysis window. It is critical that the analysis
window closely follow the stratigraphy to avoid contaminating the
seismic facies analysis with amplitudes unrelated to the features of
interest. To that end, we ﬁrst select a reference seismic event that is a
continuous, high-amplitude reﬂection and is approximately parallel
to i.e., stratigraphically concordant to the stratigraphic bodies be-
ing imaged. Then we delimit the interval of investigation using a
window of constant two-way traveltime and selecting a clustering
algorithm. We use the visual data-mining approach of Guo et al.
2005 for reasons described in part 1. Finally, we validate and inter-
pret the clustering output visually using graphic display components
and analyzing the geologic meaning of the results.
The strength of the visual strategy lies in coupling the self-orga-
nizing maps SOM; Kohonen, 1995 algorithm with visual graphic
techniques to create an efﬁcient seismic facies classiﬁcation envi-
ronment for exploring and examining patterns in complex data sets.
The SOM’s clustering output is represented using three visual tech-
niques. The ﬁrst is the uniﬁed distance matrix U-matrix; Ultsch and
Siemon, 1990. In this display, the distances between the patterns are
represented in a 2D hexagonal grid with gray shading.Acluster is an
a)
b)

Figure1.ApproximatelocationofthestudyareainsoutheasternSaskatchewan.aLoca-
tion of the main structural elements surrounding the northern part of Williston Basin
modiﬁed from Sarzalejo and Hart, 2006. b Location of the survey with respect to the
lithofacies cutoff that separates Jurassic strata of southeastern from that of southwestern
Saskatchewan modiﬁed from Kreis, 1991. The inset at the upper-right corner shows the
seismic area and well locations.

area of the SOM map represented by light shading, whereas borders
between clusters appear as dark edges. The second visual compo-
nent on the U-matrix display is the size of the dot in each node, repre-
senting the number of hits in that node. In this sense, nodes with very
few or no hits can indicate cluster borders Zhang and Li, 1993. Col-
ors are assigned to each dot using CIELab color space McLaren,
1976, and the result is a scheme with colors more equally spaced
than any other linear color space e.g., red, green, blue.
The second visual display is the multidimensional visualization of
the patterns discovered with a parallel coordinate plot PCP; Insel-
berg, 1985 using a nested-means scaling procedure. We use this vi-
sualization tool to investigate the presence of multidimensional
clusters Wegman and Luo, 1997. The PCP adaptation in the visual
strategy displays the weight vector of each SOM node as polygonal
segments, the color and thickness of which come from the U-matrix
display.
The third display is a map view of the patterns discovered, where
the seismic traces are displayed according to their x- and y coordi-
nates with a color coding from the U-matrix display. More detailed
descriptions of each of the graphic components are presented in
Marroquín et al. 2009.
An advantage of the visual data-mining approach is that the inter-
preter does not need to deﬁne a priori the number of seismic facies to
partition the seismic data. Instead, this approach is a feature-discov-
ery scheme that seeks to let the data speak. The
optimum number of seismic facies is, ideally, an
output of the method. The only requirement is to
select the grid size of the 2D SOM. We show the
results obtained with a grid of 1111 nodes to
approximate major patterns in the data. Marro-
quín 2007 evaluates other grid sizes.

EXAMPLES OF SEISMIC
FACIES ANALYSIS

We selected a 3D seismic survey located in the
northern part of the Williston Basin Figure 1.
The database consists of a conventional P-wave
3D seismic data volume and wireline logs from
30 wells in and around the seismic area. The 3D
seismic survey covers an area of approximately
56 km2 22 mi2, with a bin size of 3030 m
9898 ft and a 2-ms sampling rate. No cores
are available from the survey area, so our strati-
graphic analyses are based on the analysis and
correlation of wireline logs.
Two stratigraphic levels were chosen from the
3D seismic data volume to test the proposed visu-
al strategy’s ability to generate seismic facies
maps for different depositional environments.
The ﬁrst lower interval comprises Devonian
carbonate and evaporate deposits, and the second
interval contains Jurassic siliciclastic units. Fig-
ure 2 is a stratigraphic column that shows the
stratigraphic context of the intervals of interest.
Carbonate depositional facies

The Devonian Winnipegosis Formation Fig-
ure 2 is subdivided into three main units from

base to top: a dolomitized fossiliferous platform Jones, 1965, a reef
system composed of dolomitized carbonates Gendzwill and Wil-
son, 1987, and the Ratner Member, described as carbonate mud-
stone and/or anhydrite present only in areas without reefal buildup
Jones, 1965.The basal carbonate platform was deposited in a mod-
erately shallow open marine environment. Then, a fairly rapid trans-

Figure 2. Stratigraphic correlation chart showing a Shaunavon
Formation modiﬁed from Kreis, 1988 and b Elk Point modiﬁed
from Brown et al., 1990.

gression of the sea led to reef growth in Winnipegosis time. Uplift
near the end of Winnipegosis time caused a shallowing of the basin,
followed by a decrease of water circulation and an increase in salini-
ty.This stopped the reef growth and led to deposition of the thick salt
of the capping Prairie Evaporite Formation Brown et al., 1990.
Pinnacle reefs in theWinnipegosis Formation are visible in the 3D
volume between 1430 and 1470 ms. Figure 3a shows a west-east
seismic section through the study area. Larger reefs are character-
ized seismically by raised rims, along with a negative drape of the
Prairie Evaporite horizon. According to Brown et al. 1990 and
Anderson and Franseen 1991, these seismic characteristics are the
product of differential compaction in the reefs and between the reefs
and the encasing salt, respectively. We used the reﬂection from the
top of the Prairie Evaporite Formation as a reference for horizon-
slicing analysis see Figure 3a. This reference horizon was inter-
preted as a robust, continuous, high-amplitude reﬂection present
throughout the 3D seismic survey. Based on visual inspection of am-
plitude slices Figure 3b, we deﬁned an analysis window of 44 ms
beneath the reference horizon Figure 3a. Because of the 2-ms sam-
pling rate of our data, the seismic traces correspond to a 22-dimen-
sional analysis space.
We conducted the unsupervised clustering analysis in a rectangu-
lar subset of the seismic survey that contains 15,600 seismic traces
and corresponds to a major reef feature with two semicircular reefs
Figure 3b. The results are shown in Figure 4a-c. Visual examina-
tion of the gray shading in the U-matrix display Figure 4a shows no
obvious clusters in the SOM map. However, a ridge of darker gray
nodes cuts the display in two areas.The area on the lower left is com-
posed of green and blue patterns, whereas the area on the upper right
is made of brown, olive, red, and pink patterns. We also observe a
concentration of violet patterns in the bottom right corner of the dis-
play.
a)
b)

Figure 3. Seismic images showing the expression of Winnipegosis
pinnacle reefs. a Vertical transect through this interval. The dashed
line in the analysis window shows the level at which the amplitude
slice in part b was extracted. The size of the window analysis was set
to 44 ms. b Amplitude slice showing the reef morphology. Larger
reefs have a preferential northwest-southeast orientation, surround-
ed by minor, circular reefs. The rectangle indicates the portion of the
seismic survey used for seismic facies analysis.

In both areas, the distance map shows approximately homoge-
neous light gray shading, suggesting a high degree of similarity be-
tween most map nodes and their immediate neighbors. We attribute
this to the highly correlated and continuous nature of the data in
these areas representing gradational depositional facies bound-
aries. Additionally, the frequency-count map shows that all nodes
are active, but those located along the ridge of darker gray have few
hits i.e., smaller dots, suggesting the presence of a cluster border
Zhang and Li, 1993.
a)
b)
c)

Figure 4. Visual data-mining clustering results on Winnipegosis reef system. a The U-matrix display shows a cluster border small dots and
dark gray nodes denoted by arrows separating interreef rocks green and blue patterns from reef areas brown, olive, red, and pink patterns. b
The PCP graphic display shows the presence of three distinct associations of seismic facies indicated by patterns with 1 blue and green lines;
2 red, pink, and violet lines; and 3 brown and olive lines. cThe geographic mapping illustrates how the association of seismic facies reveals
subtle stratigraphic variations: reef-core facies are denoted by brown and olive; reef margins are deﬁned red, pink, and violet; and interreef rocks
are shown in blue and green.

The visual interpretation of the PCP graphic display Figure 4b
suggests the presence of three distinct associations of seismic facies.
The ﬁrst association is composed of patterns with blue and green
lines, the second association is formed by patterns with red, pink,
and violet lines, and the last association is represented by a small
number of patterns with brown and olive lines.
Comparison of the seismic facies map Figure 4c with the slice
through the data 54 ms below the Prairie Evaporite pick Figure 3b
indicates that inner-reef areas are characterized by seismic facies

with brown and olive, whereas the reef margins consist of a succes-
sion of seismic facies with red, pink, and violet. These observations
suggest the reef margins consist of different facies than those found
in the reef core, an observation consistent with most descriptions of
reefs e.g., Wilson, 1984. Brown et al. 1990 and Anderson and
Franseen 1991, in their study of the Winnipegosis reef system,
point out that the raised rim on the seismic data is principally be-
cause of differential compaction in the different reef facies. The
compaction probably enhances the original reef morphology and
characteristics of the reef facies Anderson and Franseen, 1991.The
interreef areas are represented by seismic facies with blue and green
in the map-view component Figure 4c. Because neither core data
nor well-log control is available for this interval, we suggest that the
changes in interreef areas are because of facies variations in the Rat-
ner Member and/or the laterally adjacent Prairie Evaporite Forma-
tion Jin and Bergman, 1999.
In light of these interpretations, we reinterpreted the distribution
of the patterns shown in the U-matrix display Figure 4a. In doing
so, it became clear that the lower-left area of that display corre-
sponds to interreef rocks and the upper-right area represents reef fa-
cies. In short, the methodology automatically distinguishes two
principal depositional environments and also discriminates individ-
ual subfacies. Note that the ridge of dark nodes in Figure 4a does not
extend entirely to the lower-right corner, the location of the violet
patterns. The violet patterns border the reef cores Figure 4c; there-
fore, the lower-right corner can be interpreted to represent the loca-
tion of seismic traces that are gradational between reef and interreef
areas i.e., reef margins.
Clastic depositional facies

The second example is a study of channels in the lower member of
the Jurassic Shaunavon Formation. We used the seismic interpreta-
tions done by Chevrier 2003 to interpret our seismic facies analy-
sis. He identiﬁes a ﬂuvial or estuarine channel with orthogonal tribu-
taries in the lower Shaunavon and suggests the study area experi-
enced a fall in sea level during Middle Jurassic time. Kreis 1991
ﬁnds evidence of incision and channel sand ﬁll in time-equivalent
strata east of our study area.
Aseismic transect through this interval is shown in Figure 5a. The
channel features are represented by discontinuous, patchy seismic
events troughs that correspond to lateral changes in polarity. Be-
cause of its continuity and stratigraphic conformity to lower
Shaunavon strata, we used the reﬂection from the top lower Van-
guard Group Figure 2 as a reference for horizon-slicing analysis.
As illustrated in Figure 5a, this event is manifested as a laterally con-
tinuous high-amplitude peak. In Figure 5b, we show a slice through
the data 42 ms below the lower Vanguard pick that displays the
channel system in the seismic survey. Note the presence of a well-de-
veloped main channel joined by three approximately orthogonal
tributaries. The south-central tributary has a clear meandering char-
acter, and the north-central tributary is straight. Based on these dis-
plays, we deﬁned an 18-ms analysis window below the reference ho-
rizon Figure 5a. This resulted in seismic traces with a nine-dimen-
sional analysis space because of the 2-ms sampling rate.
To analyze the stratigraphic variability in this area, we generated a
log cross section through the lower Shaunavon Formation and adja-
cent rocks Figure 6. This log cross section, selected on the basis of
data availability and quality, is oriented nearly parallel to the main

channel feature Figure 5b. Two wells penetrate the channel ﬁll
e.g., wells15-04 and 02-11, and their gamma-ray log shows sand-
stone at the base of the ﬁll overlain by shale. Note the presence of
shale between two sandstone intervals near the base of the channel
ﬁll in well 15-04. We consider this shale to represent mud deposited
in the abandonment phase of the channel system. Outside of the
channel, the gamma-ray logs indicate an interbedding of sandstone
and shaly strata that is typical of interﬂuvial deposits Miall, 1992.
a)
b)

Figure 5. Seismic images showing the presence of Jurassic channel
features. a Vertical transect through this interval. The dashed line
in the window analysis shows the level at which the amplitude slice
in part b was extracted. The size of the window analysis was set to
18 ms. b Amplitude slice showing the channel system. The main
channel is joined by three tributaries. The rectangle indicates the
portion of the seismic survey used for seismic facies analysis. Also
shown is the location of the log cross section Figure 6.

Figure 6. Log cross section showing the presence of channel sand-
stone ﬁll e.g., wells 15-04 and 02-11. Note the hot-shale signature
between two channel sandstone ﬁlls on well 15-04.

Some of the packages in the interﬂuvial deposits can be correlated
over distances of several kilometers, indicating stratigraphic conti-
nuity at that scale.
For the unsupervised clustering analysis, we chose a portion of the
seismic survey that includes 20,452 seismic traces and contains a
b)
a)
c)

Figure 7. Visual data-mining clustering results on Jurassic channel features. a The U-matrix display does not show a well-deﬁned cluster bor-
der line of darker nodes denoted by arrows separating channel facies red, pink, and violet patterns from adjacent rocks green, olive, brown,
and blue patterns. b The PCPgraphic display shows the presence of three distinct associations of seismic facies: the blue lines; the violet, red,
and pink lines; and the olive, green, and brown lines. c The geographic mapping depicts the spatial distribution of the seismic facies, revealing
subtle stratigraphic variations. Seismic facies with violet, red, and pink represent differences in channel-ﬁll lithology e.g., Figure 6, and lateral
changes in interﬂuve deposits are deﬁned by seismic facies in blue, green, olive, and brown.

section of the main channel along with the north- and south-central
tributaries Figure 5b. The results of the clustering analysis are
shown in Figure 7. Like the carbonate seismic facies results present-
ed earlier Figure 4a, the U-matrix display Figure 7a shows a ridge
of darker gray nodes cutting the SOM map into two areas. In each of

these areas, the distance map shows an approximately homogeneous
lightgrayshading.Thisindicatesahighdegreeofsimilaritybetween
most map nodes and their direct neighbors, suggesting gradational
facies changes. The left area consists of green, olive, brown, and
blue patterns, whereas the right area is composed of red, pink, and vi-
olet patterns. Furthermore, the frequency-count map Figure 7a
shows that all map nodes are active; thus, the cluster border associat-
ed with the ridge of darker gray is less apparent in comparison with
the carbonate example Figure 4a.
In contrast to the U-matrix display, the PCP graphic display
shown in Figure 7b suggests the presence of three distinctive associ-
ations of seismic facies.The ﬁrst association is composed of patterns
with blue lines, the second association is formed by patterns with vi-
olet, red, and pink lines, and the last association is represented by
patterns with olive, green, and brown lines.
Although the amplitude slice Figure 5b shows variability that
suggests differences in the nature of the channel ﬁll, the slice does
not capture changes in reﬂection shape that might yield more infor-
mation. The seismic facies map Figure 7c indicates the main chan-
nel is characterized by seismic facies in violet, red, and pink, which
in turn does not follow the distribution of amplitudes shown in Fig-
ure 5b. We suggest these facies represent variations in the stratigra-
phy of the channel-ﬁll successions such as those illustrated in Figure
6. Variations in lithology are to be expected in channel-ﬁll environ-
ments e.g., Miall, 1992. We also note that the same seismic facies
are present in the orthogonal tributaries. Unfortunately, our log data-
base does not allow us to compare the stratigraphic successions of
the tributaries with the main channel.
On the other hand, the interﬂuvial areas are represented by seis-
mic facies of blue, green, olive, and brown. These facies may indi-
cate changes in stratigraphic successions in interﬂuvial areas.Again,
the relatively sparse well-log control does not allow us to map out
accurately the distribution of subfacies e.g., crevasse splays that
might correspond to the different seismic facies. However, the
U-matrix display Figure 7a and the log cross section Figure 6
suggest gradational facies changes inside the channel and in the in-
terﬂuvial areas.
To summarize, the U-matrix display Figure 7a correctly deter-
mines the existence of two principal depositional environments that
correspond to channel and nonchannel deposits. Further subdivi-
sions of these facies are possible, and the presence of these subfacies
is consistent with the available log data and knowledge of facies
models for the types of environments being imaged seismically. Un-
like the reef example, which suggests the existence of two principal
facies reef versus nonreef separated by a gradational zone Figure
4a, the U-matrix display Figure 7a indicates no transitional facies
between the channel and nonchannel facies. This observation makes
geologic sense in that a facies transition from channel to interﬂuvial
areas is usually abrupt.
DISCUSSION

The visual data-mining approach is neither the ﬁrst nor the only
approach to seismic facies analysis. As such, and to benchmark our
results, we now compare them with those obtained from a commer-
cial package for seismic facies classiﬁcation. The commercial pack-
age also uses a SOM Kohonen, 1995 algorithm; unlike the 2D
SOM used here, the processing neurons are organized as a sequence
of reference vectors in one dimension. The sequence of reference
vectors retrieves the internal organization of the data points in a

manner similar to principal curves. Principal curves are smooth
curves deﬁned by the property that each point of the curve is the av-
erage of all data points that project onto it Hastie and Stuetzle,
1989.
The clustering procedure consists of deﬁning the number of itera-
tions t, learning rate parameter , and the neighborhood-size param-
eter hbik. We opted for the default values provided by the software
i.e., ini  0.7 and fin  0.01, kini  5.0 and kfin  1.5 and ran the
software up to 100 iterations. According to Coléou et al. 2003, in
the commercial package, each seismic trace from the interval of
analysis is compared with the series of synthetic seismic facies.
These model facies are created randomly for the number of facies se-
lected by the interpreter. Then, the model facies nearest to the actual
seismic trace and its neighbors are adjusted to incorporate the fea-
tures of the input trace. The entire process is repeated for all seismic
traces. Thus, the output of the classiﬁcation is a facies trace color
based on maximum correlation, in which the seismic facies map
shows similarity between seismic traces and a set of model facies.
One drawback of the commercial package is that the interpreter
also must choose the number of seismic facies K for partitioning the
data. This implies the interpreter must know the number of geologic
facies in advance. Earlier in this paper, we showed the seismic facies
classiﬁcation results generated by the visual strategy when a large
number of neurons e.g., 1111  121 nodes were used. For com-
parison, we present the results of the seismic facies classiﬁcation ob-
tained using the commercial package when K  32. The objective
behind this choice was to compare visually the ﬁne detail of the clas-
siﬁcation output and the ability to determine major patterns in the
data. Further tests were conducted where K in the commercial pack-
age was estimated at 4, 8, and 16. Grid sizes of 33, 55, 77,
and 99 were also tested in the visual strategy. Details of these re-
sults are discussed by Marroquín 2007.
The seismic facies map Figure 8a produced by the commercial
package for the Devonian pinnacle reefs clearly distinguishes the
reef areas inner facies are in brown, red, and orange, and the reef
margins are in yellow and green from the interreef rocks seismic
facies in blue and violet. This classiﬁcation is similar to the one
shown in Figure 4c. The facies classiﬁcation of the Jurassic channel
features is presented in Figure 9a. According to this result, we can
distinguish the main channel and tributaries by their seismic facies
with brown and red from the adjacent rocks deﬁned by facies of or-
ange, yellow, green, blue, and violet.Again, the classiﬁcation is sim-
ilar to the one observed in Figure 7c.
Other tests described by Marroquín 2007 demonstrate that a
gradual increase of the SOM 2D grid size or the number of model fa-
cies do not change the overall topologic ordering of the seismic fa-
cies map signiﬁcantly. This means both approaches generated simi-
lar seismic facies maps that reveal major stratigraphic features in the
two analysis windows. However, the commercial package generated
facies maps that show sharper boundaries between the two principal
depositional environments reef versus nonreef and channel versus
interﬂuvial. The visual appearance of the facies maps is because of
the sequential color scheme used to represent logically arranged
model facies e.g., K  1 to 32, regardless of their distances in the
manifold. This is in contrast to the visual strategy, wherein the in-
crease of the grid lattice led to facies maps with an improved visual
detail. In turn, this is because of the uniform color scheme, which ac-
counts for the distances of the patterns discovered in the 2D SOM
grid. Proper use of color can be a powerful technique for enhancing

the perception and interpretation of data e.g., Fortner and Meyer,
1997; Brewer, 1999.
Another difference between the two approaches is the ability of a
2D SOM to capture the variability of the seismic-trace shape better.
A 2D SOM forms an elastic net that folds onto the distribution of
multidimensional clouds formed by the input data Vesanto and Al-
honiemi, 2000. This mapping preserves the neighborhood relations
such that nearby traces are projected onto neighboring nodes in the
2D grid lattice. The clustering of the weight vectors can therefore be
regarded as the clustering of the input data. In contrast to a 2D SOM,
the sequence of reference vectors in a 1D SOM follows a curved path
to cover the distribution of the input patterns, which in turn may fail
to preserve the continuity and resolution of the seismic facies. Fur-
thermore, the input data are in fact signals; thus, there are correla-
tions between adjacent amplitude samples on a seismic trace. There-
a)
b)

Figure 8. Seismic facies classiﬁcation for Devonian reef system using a commercial package. a The facies classiﬁcation map differentiates the
reef areas i.e., inner facies are in brown, red, and orange versus reef margins are deﬁned by yellow and green from the interreef rocks seismic
facies with blue and violet. The resulting seismic facies map is similar to the classiﬁcation shown in Figure 4c. b The unsupervised model fa-
cies generated over the interval analysis.

fore, we must expect that the subjacent dimension is lower than the
original seismic-trace length.

Cover 1965 theoretically shows that the number of ways in
which N points in Rn can be partitioned into separable dichotomies is
related to the dimensionality of the mapping-feature space. In this
sense, the visual strategy provides a 2D grid lattice, plus the size of
the dots showing the number of hits in each node and their colors, re-
sulting in a mapping space with a capacity of four dimensions to
classify the seismic data set. This argues in favor of the potential use
of a 2D versus a 1D SOM.
The visual strategy has some drawbacks Marroquín et al., 2009.
First, there is the compromise of projecting n-dimensional space of
the data onto the 2D U-matrix display.As such, it is probable that the
mapped locations of some input data may be more distorted than oth-
ers. Another drawback is that the interpreter must select the size of

the SOM 2D grid to perform the classiﬁcation. Although this step is
almost similar to the preselection of number of facies in the commer-
cial package, the use of multilevel visualization techniques can
guide the interpreter’s analysis and understanding of complex data
structures present in 3D seismic data. Our tests point out the impor-
tance of using different grid sizes to identify subtle variations in the
seismic-trace shape. A third drawback is that the approach to deﬁn-
ing the natural clustering structure in the data remains subjective.
Automated interpretation of the U-matrix and PCPdisplays, i.e., au-
tomated seismic facies deﬁnition and ultimately discrimination of
geologically signiﬁcant bodies, remains elusive.
This apparent limitation of the SOM or any clustering algorithm
may be positive for geoscientiﬁc analyses. For example, West et al.
2002 argue that “Fundamental knowledge of the geology and geo-
a)
b)

Figure 9. Seismic facies classiﬁcation for Jurassic channel features with commercial package.The facies classiﬁcation map a distinguishes the
ﬂuvial deposits i.e., main channel and its tributaries by their patterns with brown and red from the nonchannel rocks, deﬁned by their patterns
with orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet. Note how the resulting seismic facies map is similar to the classiﬁcation shown in Figure 7c. bThe
unsupervised model facies generated over the interval analysis.

physics… is critical to the successful application of any technique in
an integrated workﬂow” p. 1048. In other words, automated ana-
lytical techniques are best thought of as interpretation aids and
should not be used as a substitute for human judgment. On a more
general level, Keim 2002 argues that “visualization is a major asset
when learning from data because it supports the reﬂection phase of
the learning process and also, it supports the inference process” p.
100. In this context, the visual data-mining approach of Guo et al.
2005 that we tested for seismic facies analysis proved to be quite
helpful.
Finally, both examples presented in this paper show strata that
could be classiﬁed into two principal depositional environments.
Other stratigraphic intervals are likely to be more complex. We an-
ticipate, however, that the visual strategy we used, or any similar ap-

proach that allows an interpreter to explore visually the natural clus-
tering structure of a seismic data set, should be useful in those cases.
CONCLUSIONS

In this paper, we showed that a visual data-mining approach de-
veloped by Guo et al. 2005 to analyze spatial data and described in
Marroquín et al. 2009 is a useful tool for seismic facies analysis.
Our tests conducted on seismic data that image clastic and carbonate
depositional systems demonstrate that the methodology can capture
geologically meaningful but subtle changes in the seismic trace
shape in the highly correlated and continuous seismic data. Exami-
nation of the SOM’s clustering output i.e., the U-matrix, PCP, and
map views helped to deﬁne the number of natural clusters in the
data set and whether the boundaries between those clusters are
abrupt or gradational. Based on our geologic understanding of the
two depositional systems studied, it appears the natural clusters
identiﬁed by the visual strategy each correspond to different geolog-
ic facies, thereby satisfying one of the primary objectives of seismic
facies analysis.
We compared our results to those obtained from a commercial
package to evaluate the potential of the visual strategy. Both ap-
proaches use visual graphic techniques to display the SOM’s cluster-
ing output. However, there are major differences in how the unsuper-
vised clustering reveals the distinct seismic trace patterns in the data.
In the commercial package, the interpreter must select the number of
seismic facies. This implies a priori knowledge of the number of
geologic facies. On the other hand, the visual strategy requires that
the interpreter choose only the size of the SOM 2D grid such that the
optimum number of seismic facies is, ideally, part of the output.
There is also the way in which colors are attributed.The visual da-
ta-mining approach uses a color scheme that reﬂects the distances in
the manifold of the SOM nodes, producing a ﬁner visual detail in the
seismic facies map. The commercial package, on the other hand,
uses a sequential hue transition that is not representative of the dis-
tances in the manifold of the model facies, thereby producing a seis-
mic facies map that remained insensitive to the increased output of
model facies. Another important point is that the visual strategy in-
cludes the interpreter in the data exploration and analysis, thereby
providing insights into that person’s working and hopefully in-
creasing the conﬁdence level in the results.
The visual strategy has some limitations. Fully automated cluster
analysis remains elusive, but whether this is a problem or an advan-
tage we argue for the latter remains debatable. Moreover, the de-
velopment of a better data-mapping approach for the SOM might
help
minimize
the
distortions
caused
when
projecting
n-dimensional data onto the 2D grid lattice used by the algorithm.
Finally, we recommend conducting the seismic facies analysis with
different sizes of the SOM 2D grid and at each stage, using the inte-
grated visual interpretation of the U-matrix, PCP, and map-view
components to understand the complex patterns present in a 3D seis-
mic data set.
